questions.text: A 23-year-old male is rushed to the emergency room after being involved in a street fight.Physical examination reveals a stab wound at the left sternal border in the fourth intercostal space. Which of the following structures is most likely to have been damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)  Which is the right ventricle

The right ventricle is most commonly injured in such a case because it is the most anterior cardiac chamber. Even though the stab wound is at the left sternal border in the fourth intercostal space, the heart is oriented in the thorax such that the right ventricle forms the majority of the anterior surface of the heart, lying just behind the sternum. This anatomical position makes it the structure most vulnerable to penetrating injuries in this region.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with occasional headaches. On examination, several pigmented spots on his trunk are seen with few rubbery cutaneous tumors on his neck. The cells composing these skin tumors most likely originated from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Neural crest

Neurofibromatosis Type I (NF1, or von Recklinghausen's disease) is a common autosomal-dominant disorder. Cutaneous and subcutaneous neurofibromas are common in this condition and are tumors of Schwann cells, which are embryologically derived from the neural crest.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with left arm clumsiness. Physical examination reveals motor weakness and increased muscle tone in the left arm. Specifically, with passive extension of the left arm there is initial resistance then sudden release when maximum extension is reached. Pathology within which of the following brain structures is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Exp:
•    This patient has "clasp knife spasticity," characterized by initial jerking resistance to passive extension followed by sudden release of resistance. This form of spasticity is typical of an upper motor neuron lesion.
•    Potential sites for upper motor neuron lesions include the corticospinal tracts of the spinal cord; the medulla, pons and midbrain; the internal capsule; or the precentral gyrus (primary motor cortex). Of these, the internal capsule is the only structure labeled above (Choice B).
•     In general, upper motor neuron lesions cause spastic paresis, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign. The clasp knife phenomenon is a form of spasticity that results from a lack of upper motor neuron inhibitory control on the spinal muscle stretch reflex arc.

questions.text: Due to a temporary problem with accessing the hospital patient records, the only available information for a patient is elevated urine phosphate. Based solely on this information, which of the following could have caused the phosphaturia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The proximal tubule sodium-phosphate (Na+-Pi) cotransporter is responsible for reabsorption of about 85% of filtered phosphate. A genetic defect leads to phosphaturia and contributes to calcium phosphate stone formation. Chronic renal failure presents with hyperphosphatemia and hypophosphaturia due to a decreased filtered load of phosphorus. Fruits and vegetables are low (not high) in phosphorus, a useful knowledge for patients with kidney problems. Similarly, hypo-PTH caused by removal of the parathyroid gland results in low (not high) urine phosphate.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man visits his physician and expresses concern about his upcoming trip to Leh, at an altitude of 10,000ft. The doctor prescribes acetazolamide to be taken 2 days prior and throughout his 4 day trip. Acetazolamide exerts its diuretic effect by acting on primarily which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

PCT 

PCT cells are rich in carbonic anhydrase. Carbonic anhydrase catalyses the reaction between CO2 and H2O to form H2CO3, which in turn splits into H+ and HCO3-. H+ is secreted into the tubular lumen and HCO3- is reabsorbed. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like Acetazolamide block the reabsorption of HCO3- and Na+, resulting in diuresis. Because almost all of the filtered bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the PCT, inhibiting carbonic anhydrase has little effect on bicarbonate reabsorption from other segments. 
Acetazolamide taken a few days prior to ascent to high altitude prevents the symptoms of mountain sickness due to the following: (i) prevention of fluid retention via diuresis (ii) production of metabolic acidosis from decreased bicarbonate reabsorption which offsets respiratory alkalosis in high altitude, and (iii) inhibition of pulmonary vasoconstriction.

questions.text: Regarding Brexanolone, find out the TRUE statement.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It is a GABA receptor modulator

Explanation:
•    Brexanolone is a GABA-A receptor positive allosteric modulator.
•    It is a synthetic formulation of allopregnanolone, a neurosteroid that enhances GABA-A receptor activity.
•    Used for postpartum depression (PPD), not psychosis.

Why the other options are incorrect?
•    B. Approved for postpartum psychosis (False)
o    Fact: Brexanolone is only approved for postpartum depression (PPD), not postpartum psychosis.
o    Postpartum psychosis requires antipsychotics or mood stabilizers, sometimes hospitalization.
•    C. Administered orally (False)
o    Fact: Brexanolone is given as a continuous intravenous (IV) infusion over 60 hours (2.5 days) in a hospital setting.
o    It is not available in oral form due to rapid metabolism.
•    D. Safe in renal disease since excreted by bile and feces (False)
o    Fact: Brexanolone is primarily metabolized by the liver, but it is excreted by both renal and hepatic routes.
o    Severe renal impairment (eGFR <30 mL/min) can increase drug exposure, making dose adjustments necessary.

questions.text:
Find out the true and false statements
A.    Ciprofloxacin will aggravate theophylline toxicity
B. About 97% of drugs will be excreted after five half-lives in first-order kinetics
C. Muscarinic (M4) receptor is a ligand-gated receptor
D. INH is a microsomal enzyme CYP2E1 inducer
E. ED50 of a drug indicates maximum efficacy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A - True, B - True, C - False, D - True, E – False
 Explanation:
•    A. Ciprofloxacin will aggravate theophylline toxicity (True)
o    Ciprofloxacin is a CYP1A2 inhibitor, which reduces the metabolism of theophylline, leading to increased toxicity (seizures, cardiac arrhythmias).
•    B. About 97% of drugs will be excreted after five half-lives in first-order kinetics (True)
o    In first-order kinetics, drug elimination follows a predictable pattern:
    1 half-life → 50% eliminated
    2 half-lives → 75% eliminated
    3 half-lives → 87.5% eliminated
    4 half-lives → 93.75% eliminated
    5 half-lives → ~97% eliminated
•    C. Muscarinic (M4) receptor is a ligand-gated receptor (False)
o    Muscarinic receptors (M1–M5) are all G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), not ligand-gated ion channels.
o    Ligand-gated receptors include nicotinic receptors, not muscarinic.
•    D. INH is a microsomal enzyme CYP2E1 inducer (True)
o    Isoniazid (INH) induces CYP2E1, increasing metabolism of drugs like acetaminophen, leading to a higher risk of hepatotoxicity.
•    E. ED50 of a drug indicates maximum efficacy (False)
o    ED50 (Effective Dose 50%) is the dose at which 50% of the population shows a response.
o    Maximum efficacy is measured by Emax, not ED50.

questions.text: A bacterial strain acquires resistance to an antibiotic through the uptake of free DNA fragments from a lysed bacterium. Which genetic process is responsible for this transformation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Transformation involves the uptake of naked DNA from the environment by a competent bacterium. 

This process is observed in bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria species (termed "competent bacteria").

Conjugation involves direct cell-to-cell transfer via a pilus, and transduction involves bacteriophage-mediated DNA transfer.

questions.text: World Day Health Theme for the year 2025 is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Health beginnings, hopeful futures
Explanation
The health of mothers and babies is the foundation of healthy families and communities, helping ensure hopeful futures for us all.
World Health Day, celebrated on 7 April 2025, will kick off a year-long campaign on maternal and newborn health. The campaign, titled Healthy beginnings, hopeful futures, will urge governments and the health community to ramp up efforts to end preventable maternal and newborn deaths, and to prioritize women’s longer-term health and well-being.
WHO and partners will also share useful information to support healthy pregnancies and births, and better postnatal health.
Helping every woman and baby survive and thrive
This task is critical. Tragically, close to 300 000 women lose their life due to pregnancy or childbirth each year, while over 2 million babies die in their first month of life and millions more are stillborn. That’s roughly 1 preventable death every 7 seconds.
Based on current trends, a staggering 4 out of 5 countries are off track to meet global targets for improving maternal survival by 2030.
Listening to women and supporting families
Women and families everywhere need high quality care that supports them physically and emotionally, before, during and after birth.
Health systems must evolve to manage the many health issues that impact maternal and newborn health. These not only include direct obstetric complications but also mental health conditions, noncommunicable diseases and family planning.
Additionally, women and families should be supported by laws and policies that safeguard their health and rights.
Campaign goals
•    To raise awareness about gaps in maternal and newborn survival and the need to prioritize women’s longer-term well-being.
•    To advocate for effective investments that improve the health of women and babies. 
•    To encourage collective action to support parents as well as health professionals who provide critical care.
•    To provide useful health information relating to pregnancy, childbirth, and the postnatal period.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is the most common source of severe posterior epistaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sphenopalatine artery
Sol:-
•    The sphenopalatine artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, is the most common source of severe posterior epistaxis. 
•    It supplies the posterior nasal cavity and nasal septum, where bleeding is often profuse and difficult to control. 
•    In contrast, the Kiesselbach's plexus (Little’s area) in the anterior nasal septum is the common site for anterior epistaxis, which is more common but less severe.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with fever, neck pain, and trismus. Examination reveals medial displacement of the tonsil and bulging of the lateral pharyngeal wall. A contrast-enhanced CT scan confirms a parapharyngeal abscess. Which of the following is the most life-threatening complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Descending necrotizing mediastinitis. 
Sol:-
The most life-threatening complication of a parapharyngeal abscess is descending necrotizing mediastinitis (DNM), a rapidly progressing infection that spreads from the deep neck spaces into the mediastinum.
1.    Why is DNM so dangerous?
o    The parapharyngeal space communicates with the retropharyngeal space, which extends down to the posterior mediastinum.
o    Infection can spread inferiorly along fascial planes, leading to severe sepsis, mediastinal abscess, and multi-organ failure.
o    Mortality rates can exceed 40% if not promptly diagnosed and treated.
2.    Why not the other options?
o    Cranial nerve palsy (A): Can occur due to inflammation or compression, but it is not immediately life-threatening.
o    Internal jugular vein thrombosis (B) (Lemierre’s syndrome): Can cause sepsis but is usually treatable with antibiotics and anticoagulation.
o    Acute airway obstruction (C): While serious, it is usually recognizable early and can be managed with intubation or tracheostomy.
Clinical Implications:
•    Urgent CT scan is needed to assess mediastinal involvement.
•    Immediate surgical drainage and broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (covering anaerobes and aerobes) are critical.
•    Some cases may require thoracic surgery to drain mediastinal pus.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with facial trauma after a high-impact collision. On examination, there is significant midface swelling, and he has difficulty closing his mouth. A CT scan reveals fractures involving the nasal bones, maxilla, and orbits, with disruption of the pterygoid plates. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Le Fort II fracture
Sol:-
Le Fort II fracture – A Le Fort II fracture (also known as a pyramidal fracture) involves the maxilla, nasal bones, and orbital floor, with disruption of the pterygoid plates. It results in the separation of the midface from the cranial base and is characterized by a pyramidal shape of the fracture pattern.
•    A) Le Fort I fracture involves the maxilla but does not extend to the nasal bones or orbits.
•    C) Le Fort III fracture is a craniofacial disjunction that involves the orbital and zygomatic bones, resulting in complete separation of the midface from the skull.
•    D) Zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture primarily involves the zygomatic arch and maxillary region but does not include the orbital involvement seen in Le Fort II.
A Le Fort II fracture typically presents with midface instability, nosebleeds, and dental malocclusion. Surgical stabilization is often required.

•    Radical mastoidectomy involves complete removal of the mastoid air cells, the posterior wall of the external auditory canal (EAC), tympanic membrane, and ossicles to create a large open mastoid cavity.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is found to have acute leukemia. Three weeks after initiation of chemotherapy he has a body temperature spike to 38.9 C (102 F), with a white blood cell count of 500/mm. Which of the following is true regarding this clinical situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bacteraemia, if present, would most likely be caused by pseudomonas and other gram-negative bacilli

•    The leading cause of death in cancer patients is infection. Fever developing during the course of treatment for cancer demands careful investigation for infection by all classes of pathogens: bacteria, viruses, yeasts, and protozoans.
•    Pneumonia is common but difficult to diagnose. There is scant sputum production, and often the chest roentgenographic findings are misleadingly normal. Gram-negative bacilli are responsible for most pneumonias and bacteremias.
•    The skin, mucous membranes, and catheter sites are common portals of entry. In the absence of an obvious source of infection, it is essential to begin empirical antibiotic therapy aimed at the most common organisms.
•    An antipseudomonal penicillin plus an aminoglycoside is a commonly used regimen.
•    Both chemotherapy and the tumor lysis syndrome can cause fever, but infection is much more likely to be the cause.

questions.text: A 30- year old man is noted to be hypertensive. A complete blood count reveals mild leukocytosis, hematocrit of 55% ,and thrombocytosis. Uric acid is elevated and ultrasound confirms splenomegaly. Comment on the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)   

Polycythemia vera    

•    Patients with spurious polycythemia frequently are dehydrated and volume contracted; with future –hyderation, their hematocrit may indeed normalize. 
•    There is usually no evidence of a true myeloproliferative disorder, including splenomegaly or extensive thrombocytosis. 
•    Patients with secondary polycythemia frequently have underlining chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and an elevation in red blood cell mass as a compensatory mechanism. 
•    Patients with true polycythemia vera usually have significant splenomegaly, elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase, and frequently also exhibit leukocytosis and thrombocytosis.

questions.text: A 30 yr old male presented with silvery scales on elbow and knee, which bleed on removal. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The most probable diagnosis is Psoriasis, which is a chronic inflammatory skin disorder characterized by well-demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery-white scales, commonly found on extensor surfaces like the elbows and knees. A hallmark clinical feature of psoriasis is the Auspitz sign, where pinpoint bleeding occurs upon removal of the scales — exactly what is described in the question. Psoriasis most often affects adults in their 20s to 40s and typically presents with symmetrical lesions on extensor areas, scalp, and lower back. The presence of silvery scales and bleeding on removal is very specific and points strongly toward psoriasis.

Incorrect Options:

A. Pityriasis rosea: This condition usually begins with a single herald patch followed by multiple smaller lesions in a Christmas tree pattern on the trunk. The scales are typically fine and not silvery, and bleeding on scale removal (Auspitz sign) is not a feature. It is not localized to elbows or knees, and hence does not match the described presentation.

B. Pityriasis versicolor: Caused by Malassezia furfur, this is a fungal infection that presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules mostly on the upper trunk, neck, and upper arms. The lesions are usually non-scaly or have very fine scaling, and there is no Auspitz sign. It does not typically involve the elbows and knees.

D. Lichen Planus (LP): LP is characterized by violaceous, polygonal, flat-topped, itchy papules, often involving the wrists, ankles, and mucosal surfaces. The scales, if present, are not silvery, and bleeding on removal is not a typical feature. Moreover, the classical distribution of LP is different from the extensor pattern seen in psoriasis.

questions.text: Treatment of Secondary hyperparathyroidism is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Unlike primary hyperparathyroidism, medical management is the mainstay of treatment for secondary hyperparathyroidism. 
Treatment with calcitriol and calcium can either prevent or minimize secondary hyperparathyroidism. Control of the serum phosphate levels with a low-phosphate diet and phosphate-binding agents is essential. 
Patients with dialysis-dependent chronic renal failure require calcitriol, oral calcium supplementation, calcium in the dialysate, aluminum-free phosphate binders, and cinacalcet to maintain levels of serum calcium and phosphate within normal ranges. Surgical care 
Indications include bone pain or fracture, pruritus, and calciphylaxis.

questions.text: X-ray spine of a patient with chronic back pain shows characteristic appearance of cod fish vertebrae. What is the investigation of choice to diagnose the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

DEXA 

Cod fish vertebrae in X-ray spine is suggestive of osteoporosis. The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA). It measures the bone mineral density of an individual. These measurements are made at the lumbar spine or the hip. These measured values are compared using T scores. A T score ≤ -2.5 SD is suggestive of osteoporosis.

This fracture refers to an intraarticular fracture that separates the palmar ulnar aspect of the first metacarpal base from the remaining first metacarpal. The injury is typically caused by axial loading on a partially flexed metacarpal and may be associated with other carpal bone fractures or ligament injuries

questions.text: 20 % Intralipid bolus was administered during resuscitation. Why?

•    Mechanism: it increases the rate of recovery of blocked sodium channels by decreasing cardiac bupivacaine concentration.

questions.text: What is the most common psychiatric comorbidity seen in patients with obsessive compulsive disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Depression

Persons with OCD are commonly affected by other mental disorders. The lifetime prevalence for major depressive disorder in persons with OCD is about 67 percent and for social phobia about 25 percent. Other common comorbid psychiatric diagnoses in patients with OCD include alcohol use disorders, generalized anxiety disorder, specific phobia, panic disorder, eating disorders, and personality disorders. OCD exhibits a superficial resemblance to obsessive-compulsive personality disorder, which is associated with an obsessive concern for details, perfectionism, and other similar personality traits. The incidence of Tourette’s disorder in patients with OCD is 5 to 7 percent, and 20 to 30 percent of patients with OCD have a history of tics.

questions.text: Tourette’s syndrome is associated with all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stereotypic Movement disorders
 

Up to half of all patients with Tourette’s disorder also have ADHD, and up to 40 percent of those with Tourette’s disorder also have OCD An autoimmune process and, in particular, one that is secondary to group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal infections was hypothesized as a potential mechanism for the development of tics and obsessive-compulsive symptoms in some case.. Stereotypic movement disorders, including movements such as rocking, handgazing, and other selfstimulatory behaviors, seem to be voluntary and often produce a sense of comfort, in contrast to tic disorders. Although tics in children and adolescents may or may not feel controllable, they rarely produce a sense of well-being.

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student comes to the emergency room with elevated heart rate, sweating, and shortness of breath. The student is convinced that she is having an asthma attack and that she will suffocate. The symptoms started suddenly during a car ride to school. The student has had episodes such as this on at least three previous occasions over the past 2 weeks and now is afraid to leave the house even to go to school. She has no history of asthma and, other than an increased pulse rate, physical findings are unremarkable. Of the following, the most effective immediate treatment for this patient is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A benzodiazepine 

This patient is showing evidence of panic disorder with agoraphobia. Panic disorder is characterized by panic attacks, which include increased heart rate, dizziness, sweating, shortness of breath, and fainting, and the conviction that one is about to die. Attacks commonly occur twice weekly, last about 30 minutes, and are most common in young women, such as this patient. This young woman has also developed a fear of leaving the house (agoraphobia) which occurs in some patients with panic disorder. While the most effective immediate treatment for this patient is a benzodiazepine because it works quickly, the most effective long-term (maintenance) management is an antidepressant, particularly a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) such as paroxetine (Paxil). The neural etiology most closely involved in panic disorder with agoraphobia is hypersensitivity of the locus ceruleus.

questions.text:

A-Repression and Reaction formation are the defence mechanisms in this B- Drug of choice is SSRI 
C- Risperidone can be used as an augmenting agent 
D- Systemic Desensitization is the psychotherapy of choice 
Which of these statements are true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A,B and C are true SSRI are drugs of choice in OCD. 

Risperidone is used an augmenting agent in resistant cases, exposure and response prevention is the psychotherapy of choice (and not systemic desensitization). 
Defense mechanisms used in OCD are splitting, repression, reaction formation, undoing and isolation of affect

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about combined oral contraceptive pills?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

COC pills increase the risk of femur neck factures

Combined OC pill’s predominant component is progesterone. Progesterone is known to increase the viscosity of cervical mucus and hence ascending infection risk is reduced so the risk of PID is reduced. Combined OC pills increase the risk of adenocarcinoma of endocervix slightly. Combined oc pills reduce the risk of osteoporosis and hence femur fractures are not increased because of COC pills. Combined OC pills lead to suppression of LH and FSH and hence ovarian function is suppressed. Hence combined oc pills are known to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Endometrial ablation therapy is allowed only if patient has completed her child bearing function.

Red degeneration of fibroids should be treated by conservative management. It happens during pregnancy. The most common fibroid type is intramural fibroid. Any patient with submucosal pedunculated fibroid which is also called FIGO-0 fibroid must be treated by hysteroscopic myomectomy if the fibroid is symptomatic. Endometrial ablation therapy is done only if patient doesn’t want to conceive in future because this therapy will burn out the endometrium, making the patient infertile. This is the treatment for menorrhagia due to fibroid uterus. It is done only if her childbearing function is over.

questions.text: In which of the following clinical scenarios, laparoscopic tubal ligation is not recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

After full term delivery

laparoscopic tubal ligation may not be immediately recommended for postpartum patients in all cases, especially in the early postpartum period. The reason for this is that after childbirth, the body is still undergoing significant changes, and there are some factors to consider:

•   Technical difficulty: In the immediate postpartum period, especially if performed shortly after delivery, there may be anatomical changes that make the procedure more difficult or risky, such as uterine enlargement or increased blood flow.

•   Increased risk of complications: Performing the procedure too soon after delivery could increase the risk of complications like infection or bleeding. It's generally advised to wait a few weeks to a few months post-delivery (typically 6 weeks) to allow for recovery before proceeding with sterilization.

questions.text:
A 5-week-old male infant presents to the emergency department after experiencing 2 days of persistent vomiting. The vomit is projectile and yellow, and the infant is unable to tolerate 2-ounce feedings. He has not had any diarrhoea, constipation, or abdominal distension. Despite these symptoms, the infant remains alert and active. His vital signs are as follows: heart rate of 136 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 86/52 mm Hg. Examination reveals dry mucous membranes, a capillary refill time of less than 2 seconds, and a non-distended abdomen. The liver edge is palpable 2 cm below the costal margin, and bowel sounds are present. Abdominal ultrasonography shows thickening of the pyloric muscle without other abnormalities.
Of the following, the MOST likely laboratory finding in this infant is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The infant in this vignette has projectile vomiting, clinical features of dehydration, and thickening of the pylorus muscle on ultrasonography, all of which favor a diagnosis of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The excessive vomiting leads to loss of large amounts of gastric hydrochloric acid (hydrogen and chloride ions). Of the options shown, the laboratory evaluation most likely to be found is a low serum chloride level and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic with concerns of severe muscle weakness and difficulty with motor skills. The parents report that the baby has been unusually floppy, struggling to hold up his head, and has exhibited poor feeding and lethargy. Additionally, the infant has had episodes of hypoglycemia, characterized by irritability. Physical examination reveals a prominent, enlarged liver, and signs of cardiomyopathy, including an abnormal heart murmur and signs of heart failure. Given the combination of generalized floppiness, cardiomyopathy, and hypoglycemia, further diagnostic evaluations are warranted. 
 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pompe Disease

Pompe Disease is a glycogen storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase, leading to accumulation of glycogen in muscle tissues. This condition typically presents in infancy with hypotonia, cardiomyopathy, and can cause hypoglycemia due to impaired glycogen metabolism. The cardiac involvement and muscle weakness align with Pompe disease's clinical features.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic with a history of progressive bowing of the legs and an unusual "windswept" deformities. The parents report that the child has been experiencing difficulty walking and has noticeable lower limb deformities. On evaluation, the child is noted to have a calcium level 9.1mg/dl, phosphorus levels 2mg/dl, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels 70pg/ml. Despite adequate calcium intake, the child’s phosphorus levels remain persistently low.
Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hypophosphatemic Rickets

Hypophosphatemic Rickets is characterized by low phosphorus levels in the serum, which leads to impaired bone mineralization and results in rickets. This condition is often due to a defect in renal phosphate reabsorption, such as in X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets (also known as phosphate-wasting rickets). The normal calcium levels and normal PTH levels are consistent with this diagnosis, as hypophosphatemic rickets primarily affects phosphorus metabolism rather than calcium metabolism or PTH regulation.

questions.text: In a 3 months old child with recurrent respiratory infections, which vaccine should not be given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Severe B cell immunodeficiency  (X-linked agammaglobulinemia): live vaccines including all live (BCG), oral typhoid and live viral (OPV, MMR, measles, varicella, and live attenuated influenza) are contraindicated.

questions.text:
A 12 years old has history of cyanosis. His X Ray is shown. 
 
What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Supracardiac TAPVC

In total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC), X-ray findings typically include an enlarged heart shadow due to right atrial and ventricular enlargement, reflecting increased blood flow from the pulmonary veins. The classic radiographic sign is a “snowman” or “figure-of-eight” appearance of the cardiac silhouette, particularly in the supracardiac type, where the abnormal pulmonary veins form a distinct configuration. Additionally, there may be evidence of pulmonary venous congestion with increased pulmonary markings and potentially signs of right-sided heart failure. These findings are critical in diagnosing TAPVC and assessing the severity of the condition.

questions.text: A 10 yrs old is brought to your clinic. Which vaccine should be given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

According to the Universal Immunization Programme (UIP) of India and WHO guidelines, the recommended vaccine at 10 years of age (and again at 16 years) is:

Td (Tetanus and reduced-dose Diphtheria toxoid)

Explanation of options:

A. TT (Tetanus Toxoid):

•   Used in the past, but now replaced by Td for better protection (covers diphtheria too).

B. DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus):

•   Not given after 7 years of age due to increased risk of adverse reactions from the pertussis component (especially whole-cell).

C. Td:

•   Recommended for children ≥7 years, adolescents, and adults.

•   Contains reduced diphtheria and tetanus toxoids (less reactogenic than DPT).

D. Others:

•   Not specific; doesn't apply as directly as Td in this age group.

choices.text: Rectal prolapse is most common complication after treatment

questions.text: A 9 years old boy has recurrent sino-pulmonary infections and greasy stools. Which of the following is commonly seen in the boy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

DIOS is common in adolescents with cystic fibrosis
Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome (DIOS) in cystic fibrosis occurs due to thick, viscous mucus causing bowel obstruction. This condition presents with abdominal pain, distension, and constipation. X-rays may show a dilated bowel loop. DIOS requires prompt treatment, often including hydration, enemas, and sometimes surgical intervention.

May be at risk of mitral valve prolapse
